TEXT: Good morning.
My name is Mike Roney.
I'm the new Chairman at NEXT.
This morning, I thought I would share with you several things.
First of all, a bit about my professional background.
Second, why I took the chairmanship at NEXT.
And third, some of my views on the culture at NEXT, and the positive views on the culture.
After completing university in the U.S., I joined Goodyear.
And I was sent to Latin America, went to Buenos Aires.
I spent the next 18 years in Latin America, running different operations in Latin America for Goodyear.
And I spent 12 years in Brazil.
After that time, I moved to Europe.
I went to Brussels, and I became the head of a joint venture between Goodyear Tire and Dunlop Tire.
It's a joint venture based in Brussels.
We had about 18,000 employees, 12 factories, EUR 4.5 billion of turnover.
Then in 2003, I joined the board of Bunzl as a Non-Executive Director.
I didn't have any idea what would happen 2 years later, but 2 years later, I became the Chief Executive of Bunzl, 2005.
I was Chief Executive in 2005 until April 2016.
I retired in April 2016 and joined the board of NEXT in February of this year.
When I was in the interview process, one of the questions that was posed to me is, why do you want to be Chairman of NEXT?
And the first thought that came into my mind is I looked at this company, saw a long history of success, a long-standing executive team, led by Simon.
I said, they must be doing something very well.
Also my view on retail, I always thought it was a business of relatively low margins compared to what I've been used to.
Then when I saw a business making 19% operating margins, it confirmed my view that they're doing something very well.
Second, the culture at NEXT for me felt very comfortable.
And it felt very similar to the culture at Bunzl.
What is that culture?
Culture at NEXT is an intense focus on building shareholder value.
Something that everybody in the company is focused on.
Second, they focused on the little things.
Getting little things right, working on the little things day in, day out.
And I believe little things matter.
And if you get the little things right, the big things and the results take care of themselves.
Another thing that they do at NEXT that we try to do at Bunzl is always try new things, but try them on a small scale.
Try it here, try it there.
If it works, then you push it forward on a much larger scale.
If it doesn't work, you pull back.
It's what I would call managed risk.
You have to keep taking risk in any business, but do it on a small scale.
If it works, you push forward.
Certainly, it's a company where the people are passionate about the company, passionate about the brand, passionate about the product.
And I see that throughout the organization.
Also good performers advance.
People that do well move up into the company.
And finally, it's an executive team that looks very frankly at the results.
And if they make mistakes, they admit them.
They face them, they learn from them and move forward.

So I believe that in spite of a very tough and changing retail environment, the strong executive team led by Simon, it's our job as a board to challenge that executive team, but I think over time, we all together are going to build shareholder value.
Simon?
I'd had to work very hard over the last 6 months not to call Mike John.
It's a (inaudible) so I just say Chairman now.
I'm going to start by giving a sort of a flavor of this -- of the presentation today by relating a story, which might cheer you up a little bit.
The story Chairman John mentioned when he went to Russia to see Boris Yeltsin, who is renowned for going on and on and on, a bit like these presentations.
He said to him -- he said, "Mr.
President, in one word, how is the Russian economy?"
And the President said, "Good."
And he knew it wasn't good.
So he said, "In slightly more than one word."
He said, "Not good."
And that sort of I think is a good background for this presentation because the numbers are not good.
The first half has been very, very tough, and we anticipate the rest of this year will be difficult.

But we can see some chinks of light that are giving us a little bit more confidence, not just about the balance of the year, but also about the shape of the company over the next 3 to 5 years and the areas of growth that we think we can push.
In terms of the numbers, overall full price sales down 1.2% in the first half, total sales down 2.2%.
Big difference there is the drop in markdown sales.
I'm going to talk a bit more about that in detail later.
Profits down 9.8%.
Again, these figures are characterized by retail sales down, retail profits down, Directory sales up, Directory profits up.
Interest down.
That is about the average amount of debt the company has outstanding at any one point in time.
The reason it was larger -- there was a larger debt, average debt last year was because the return of cash to shareholders was very front-ended.
Profit before tax, down 9.5%.
Taxation down to 18.5%.
This is the rate that we expect for the full year.
Combination of 2 things: firstly, decline in corporation tax rate in the U.K.
; secondly, our overseas businesses have -- are growing faster than the main business, and some of them have lower tax rates than the U.K.
Profit after tax, down 7.8%.
Earnings per share, down 6.2%.
The difference being the result of the buybacks we did at the beginning of last year.
Ordinary dividends held.
In terms of cash flow, cash flow looks strong.
Capital expenditure, down on last year.
In terms of the projection for the full year, we anticipate that what we told you last time was GBP 130 million.
It looks that will be closer to GBP 122 million, GBP 3 million coming out of warehousing and the rest coming out of stores.
Working capital.
Big swing in working capital.
The reason is because last year, we were still seeing a significant increase going through into Directory debt.
And then that was the tail-end effect of us lowering minimum payments and the increased time consumers were taking to pay down their debt.
That effect has moderated, so we see less capital flowing out into Directory debt.
Tax paid, down on last year.
This is all about a tax refund or rebate, I'm not sure what the right word -- refund, where we had paid some tax in the past that we repaid back.
In terms of distribution to shareholders, GBP 64 million by way of special dividend in the first half.
Since then, another dividend has been paid in August and another one declared for November.
And it is our intention to pay a fourth one as we sit out at the beginning of the year, which should take the full amount of special dividends to around GBP 260 million.
In terms of the balance sheet.
Stock on the balance sheet at the half year are 0.3%.
Don't be deceived by this.
This isn't because we expect sales to be up 0.3%.
This is a combination of full price stock being down 4% and markdown stock being up 20%.
The increase in markdown stock is as a result of the relative underperformance of the sale on the first few days, which came just before the year end.
As we stand today, I should say, our stock -- full price stock on last year is down about 0.2 -- about 2%.
Debt is up GBP 49 million.
Virtually all of that increase in debt comes from Directory debt.
Directory debt, up GBP 44 million.
That's on the back of credit sales up 1%.
The difference between the growth in the Directory debt and the credit sales is the very tail end of the extension of [interim] payments.
Moving on to creditors.
Big swing in creditors, which you should largely ignore, because the swing has been caused by the valuation of hedging instruments.
This time last year, we had a notional profit in our hedging instruments.
And this year, we have a notional loss.
These aren't real losses or real gains.
They're just the valuation of the hedging instruments at the time of the half year.
And dividends payable increased, that's because this year we had special dividend.
We had a special dividend payable that we didn't have last year.
Net debt, down on last year.
Again, that's about the timing of the distribution of cash to shareholders.
We said at the beginning of the year that we intended year-end debt to maintain at about GBP 860 million.
Operational cash flow, we have GBP 310 million -- we expect to have, I should say, GBP 310 million.
Special dividends, we expect to be around GBP 260 million, of which 3 quarters have been declared.

The balance, GBP 50 million, we're now confident enough in our forecast for the full year to use that GBP 50 million, which we intend to use for buybacks, subject to market conditions, share price and all the usual caveats.
Moving on to the detail in our retail business, and these are the numbers that look a little bit uncomfortable.
Total retail sales, down 8.3%.
Full price sales, down 7.7%.
Sales from new space, up, gave us 2.5% growth in sales from new space.
In terms of the performance of the new space, on -- against its targets, if you take the total portfolio of new space that we've opened over the year, those stores are about 5% on [our] target.

That shouldn't come as too much of a surprise because the whole business is down on its target, certainly since the time that these stores would have been appraised, which is about 18 months to 2 years ago.
[So that means we'd have] been contracting for them.
Our payback has missed our 24-month criteria, our hurdle rate.
And the thing I would like to stress at this point is that we have not extended our payback hurdles, it's because we've missed our targets, not because we've relaxed our payback criteria.
And we intend to, going forward, we will still stick to our payback criteria of 24 months.
And indeed, in today's environment, we think that is even more important.
Store profit of the new portfolio, still very healthy at 23%.
That's the net margin contribution before central overheads.

In terms of the reason for the miss, if you look just the new stores we opened or where we moved stores to a brand-new shop, those stores missed their target by 3%, and payback was very close to the 24-month hurdle rate.
If you look, where we really missed it was on 5 stores where we extended the stores slightly, so gained relatively small amount of space, but refit the entire store.
And in those stores, we really missed it.
So 46-month payback.
Still internal rate of return over a 10-year lease is around 23%.
It's not a disaster, but way outside of our criteria and not a mistake we plan on repeating.
I should explain though that the nature of that expenditure was all in stores that are very important to the group.
Big city center stores, which not only make a lot of profit themselves, but also say something about the brand.
This is a picture of our Birmingham Bullring store before we refit it.
That's the men's wear floor.
This is a picture of what it looked like once we'd done it.
This is the women's wear floor as it looked before.
And this is what it looked like after we refit it.
And these shops, we really did make a dramatic difference to the look and feel of the shops.
And I think the mistake we made is we overestimated how much sales benefit we get from that.

I guess, it's a mistake that we shouldn't have made because it's the story over and over again of people having big cosmetic refit programs and realizing that they don't give a huge amount of sales in the short term.
However, looking at those stores, I would still go back and spend the same amount of money on them.
I think the difference is we would have to class the spend as cosmetic refit.
I -- the money that we have to spend just to keep our store portfolio looking good.
And it's important that however difficult times are, we continue to maintain the look and feel of our shops, and don't allow them to slip to look like the shop that Birmingham was.

What that means is that we've estimated over the next 5 years, our maintenance CapEx, which we -- cosmetic refit CapEx, which we've always said to be around GBP 11 million, we think that, that will move up to near a GBP 16 million a year, so a difference of around GBP 5 million.
In the context of the GBP 800 million -- GBP 900 million of the cash we're generating, not an enormous amount.
But it's important that we don't on skimp on our stores.
Just in terms of space.
This year, we've increased space by around 85,000 square feet.
6 months ago, I told you that number was going to be near 150,000.
There are 3 reasons why it's not 150,000.
First is that we've opened more concessions.
These concessions are normally in space that got very low pounds per square foot for us, so we put a caf in.
But those concessions are taking up around 14,000 square feet.
So that's come off on that trading space.
We have a few stores -- 3 stores have slipped from this store this year into next year.
So that's just the timing of the opening rather than being in December, it will be in February.
And the biggest reason is the amount of stores that we've closed.
So you can see we closed 13 stores and moved 15 of them.
So just looking at in terms of total store numbers, although the square footage has gone forward, the total amount of stores has come down by 8.
Just like to talk a little bit about the stores we've closed, because I think it gives a good feel for a theme that I'll be developing throughout the presentation.
And that is the fact that we are very active about making sure that the store portfolio does not carry unprofitable stores.
If I take those 13 stores, 10 of them had a lease expiry, 2 of them we sublet, and 1 of them we rebooted out for redevelopment and will be moving back in, in a year or so time.
Of those stores, the ones that we actually closed rather than ones that we've redeveloped made GBP 2.1 million of profit.
So they weren't unprofitable, but they were all getting very close to the edge.
When a store is making sort of around GBP 100,000, GBP 200,000 and relatively low percentage, we take the view, at lease end, that we'll close it.
We're not going to wait for those stores to make a loss.
What this doesn't account for is the fact that just as when we open stores, we will pick up or we'll lose sales elsewhere.
Sort of when you close stores, you get a little bit of reverse cannibalization as well.
But I think what this stresses is: one, our willingness to close stores; and two, the rates at which we can close stores.
The fact that we closed 13 in just a half year is reflective of that.
And what it all comes down to is the flexibility of our store portfolio.
This graph shows the amounts of -- the percentage of our leases by value that will have expired after a given number of years.
What you can see is that within just under 6 years, half our leases will have expired.
And within 10 years, over 70% of our leases will have expired.
So we do have a lot of flexibility in terms of our ability to resize and renegotiate our lease portfolio.

Moving -- coming back from the brief tour from the really bad news, retail profit's down 33%, combination of declining like-for-likes, poorer markdown and some one-off cost increases in the cost base such as national living wage and rents review.
In terms of margin movement, slight attrition in bought-in gross margin.
This was down to a change in freight rates.
International freight rates have moved up a little bit over the last 6 months.
Markdown cost us 0.5%.
And what you can see is that actually, all things being equal, with 6% less stock going into the end of season sale, you would expect markdown sale -- you would expect our clearance rates to improve.
The less stock you have going into a sale, the more likely you are -- the bigger percentage of it you normally clear.
That didn't happen, and the markdown sales were down 14%.
That's cost us a lot of money.
It cost us about GBP 11 million.
The reasons for that, we think, are threefold, although we're unsure as to the balance, as to which reason is worth how much.
But the 3 reasons are as follows.
First of all, we were trying to clear the stock that we knew wasn't right in the first place.
Most of this stock was quarter -- stock that we'd introduced into our stores in quarter 1, and we knew that those ranges weren't right.

Secondly, although we had our sale at exactly the same time as last year, relative to the rest of the market, we looked late and later than usual because a lot of our key competitors move their sales forward.
Next year, we'll move our sale forward by at least 1 week.
The third reason, and I think this is the most important and difficult to gauge, is that we think our ability to clear stock in end-of-season sales is beginning to reduce.
And the reason for that is because of all the good work we've done in clearing stock on our clearance -- through our clearance website.
So at any time of the year now, customers can go on to our website, click on the Offers tab, and they will be able to get access to last season's sales stock.
That -- over the years, that has had a huge effect in helping us improve our markdown.
But I think it's beginning to catch up with us in the stores now.
Those customers who would have queued up at 5:00 in the morning are actually thinking, "I won't get up 5:00 in the morning, I'll go on the website once it's sold back online."
So in recognition of that, we've assumed in our forecasts that our clearance rates at the end of season will also be down on last year.
So achieved gross margin, down 0.6%.
Store payroll, this, you won't necessarily have been expecting.
Store payroll actually went down faster than sales.
And this is all about the efficiency measures that we've introduced into the stores.
Had we done nothing, then the increase -- inflationary costs in wages would have meant that wages would have been about 0.6% -- would have had a 0.6% adverse impact on margin.
The balance of 0.8% is all about all the work we've done to improve the efficiency of staffing in our stores.
And a lot of that is about the introduction of new systems, the development of our shift marketplace.
We've rewritten our [road training] program.
We've changed the bonus system used for delivery and behind-the-scenes, changed the bonus system used for replenishment.
And all of those small improvements added together have given us a significant benefit in the year.
Store occupancy costs, big adverse movement.
This is all about negative like-for-likes.
Underlying rental inflation at review is 0.
Warehousing and distribution, no increases in actual picking costs or cost per units.
Again, this is about deleveraging over fixed overheads.
Central overheads, exactly the same effect.

These are the product teams, HR, finance, and drop in sales meant that -- their drop in sales hasn't been matched by drop in costs, which has given us a sort of GBP 5 million, GBP 6 million increase in relative costs.
Overall margin movement of minus 3.5%.
We expect a similar margin movement in retail for the full year, not quite as bad.
So we're expecting that 2.9% attrition in margin for the full year.
So expecting margins of around 11.8% for the full year, 14.7% -- as against 14.7% last year.
Directory, very different picture.
Sales, up 5.7%.
Full price sales up 7.4%.
Full price sales, in terms of the breakdown of those sales, the U.K.
sales were up 3%.
And that broke down between NEXT Directory U.K.
and LABEL.
NEXT Directory U.K., this is the NEXT branded stock, was down 4%.
LABEL was up 40%.
We think the main reason for the miss on NEXT brands U.K.
is the rent problems that we had.
But there is definitely some attrition from LABEL -- that's coming from LABEL and taking sales away from retail.
We believe, in all the analysis we've done, is that the incremental sales weigh out -- they outweigh significantly the costs of cannibalization.
But we think there is some cannibalization there.
The reason we're confident there's not that much cannibalization is when you look at the quarter-by-quarter figures.
So what I've broken down here is the quarter 1 and quarter 2 figures.
And you can see that quarter 1, where we had the biggest range problems, actually U.K.
was minus 7 and moved to minus 1 in the third -- in the second quarter.
And that was against an improving performance on LABEL.
So it looks like the improving performance on LABEL hasn't detracted from the recovery in the NEXT brand.
In terms of overseas, an increase in overseas of 31%.
That sounds much more impressive than it actually is.
Constant currency, around 13%.
We're expecting constant currency increase in our overseas business of around 10% in the current year.
Customer base, 3% increase in the U.K.
customer base, 6% increase overseas.

In terms of the 3% U.K., growth in cash customers, these are the customers, they're not necessarily using cash, they may be using credit cards but they're not using our account, so all the growth has come from new cash customers.
The point to note here is that the credit customers aren't down on last year.
So we do seem to at least stabilized our credit customer base for the moment.
In terms of margin movements, margins edged forward 0.1% in Directory.
Bought-in gross margin, big adverse movement of 0.8%.
We've got the same 0.1% attrition in gross margins from the freight effect that we saw in retail.
The balance of 0.7% is all about the fact -- is mainly about the fact that the bought-in gross margins on LABEL stock are lower than they are in NEXT stock.
And overseas bought-in gross margins are lower than they are in the U.K.
So that's the reflection of LABEL and overseas growing faster than our core U.K.
business.

Markdown, a positive movement in terms of margin, but that positive movement isn't because we improved clearance rates, it's because our full price sales moved forward so much more than our markdown sales.
Actually, you can see the same effect, though not as extreme, but with stock for sale up 1%, our markdown sales were down 4%.
So we still got this attrition in our ability to clear sales stock in Directory.
It just wasn't as extreme as it was in retail.
So achieved gross margin, down 0.6%.
Interest income, down 0.2%.
This isn't because our interest income was down, it was up.
It just didn't grow as fast as total sales.
Warehousing and distribution, a 0.3% improvement.
This is because our picking and packing process have both been improved.
They're both in production at sort of tail end of last year, and the benefits we're getting from that are continuing to flow through into cost reduction.
Photography and catalogs.
This is all about the fact that a few of our customers want catalogs, and we're reducing the number of catalogs that we're producing.
Now we're not going to suddenly stop producing them because the ones that we do send them to definitely respond positively to them.
But that number is declining.
And as it's declining, we're reducing the amount of catalogs we're publishing.
That saves us money.
The amount of money we save doing that, we're investing all of that in basically improving our online marketing and systems capabilities.
Central overheads.
A positive movement of 0.6%, and this is all about Directory sales growing faster than the fixed overheads that are largely shared with retail.

And what you'll notice in that last point, I think this, again, is an important theme I'll develop a little bit later on, is that the 0.6% gain in Directory and leverage over fixed overheads in cash turns is almost exactly the same, if not slightly more, than the loss from leverage -- deleverage in retail over central overheads.
So there's about a GBP 5 million in retail -- GBP [0.5] million loss in retail, GBP 5 million gain in Directory.
That shouldn't surprise you because the total sales to the group haven't changed much, and this is all about the costs that they share.
We expect full year margins of around 25%.
Moving on to the outlook.

Three things to talk about: retail profitability and how we see our stores moving forward; secondly, an update on the progress we've made in terms of improving Directory, systems and marketing; and thirdly, a little bit about the consumer environment.
Starting with the trickiest one, retail.
And the question I think we've got to ask ourselves and certainly has been asked generally is, are retail shops an asset or a liability?
Now there are those who take the view, an understandable view, that retail shops are a millstone around any retailer's neck, and they will drag them down into oblivion.
We don't share that view.
And whilst we recognize that our retail business is likely to decline in turnover and profit, we still think it's an asset rather than a liability.
So it's an asset with a declining value, but nonetheless an asset.
We don't think it will ever be a drain on the company's resources.
So a decline in financial value, but at the same time, and this is something that's very difficult to quantify in terms of money, it is becoming an increasing asset to our Directory business.
And we see it as an intrinsic part of the online service that we offer.
And it's interesting that even companies like Amazon are beginning to have a physical presence.

So whilst we can't be sure as to what's going to happen in retail, we are fairly confident that in one form or another, not necessarily in the same shape or size or cost as they are today, there will be some form of retail presence for clothing shops going forward.
What I'm going to do now is just develop the narrative that we started to talk about 6 months ago, which I know you all found absolutely riveting, and you're going to be delighted to come back to it.
This is a graph that shows the profitability of our stores.
You'll all be familiar with this because you saw it last time.
What happens to the profitability of our portfolio in the event that we have 3 different scenarios over the next 10 years: minus 2% like-for-like growth, minus 4%, minus 6%.
And you can see the profitability, as we said last time, would be 19%, 15% and 10%.

And the assumptions we've made on that, although we won't open any new space, that unprofitable stores are closed on or around lease expiry and that profitable stores are held over at the end of their lease.
So we wouldn't necessarily renew them for any period of time, but we would just hold over at the passing rent without any rent reductions.
And certainly, in today's environment, that is, in many case, the worst case.
Normally, we'd get better than that.
And the other thing to bear in mind is that 70% of our leases, as I said before, will expire within 10 years.
Developing that a little bit further, let's go to that bottom scenario.
And I would like to just stress, because whenever you do these things, they will think that whatever you put up on the screen is your forecast.
This is our worst case scenario, not our forecast for the business.
But our worst-case scenario is that at that minus 6% compound annual decline in sales, that stores would generate a net branch contribution before central overheads of around GBP 100 million of cash.
That begs the question, could they support the central overheads of the business?
And I just want to go into how we see the central overheads being managed were this scenario to play out.
At the moment, the central overheads of the business are around GBP 230 million.
This is -- these are cash costs.
So they -- doesn't include depreciation, does include an allowance, GBP 16 million allowance for maintenance.
And if we break that down into the constituent parts.
It's GBP 40 million in marketing, GBP 50 million in warehousing, GBP 60 million of distribution and GBP 80 million of central overheads.
These are largely the departments that are shared with Directory, such as our product departments, HR departments.
Within each one of those areas, there is actually quite a lot of variable costs.
If we pick less in our warehouses, we'll spend less money on pickers.
If we have fewer stores, then marketing costs will come down because a lot of that cost are window dressers.
Fewer stores, fewer windows, fewer window dressers.
If we say the minus 6% scenario would give us a drop in sales of 57%, the reason that that's more, I can see instantly you've all added it up, 6% compound, couldn't possibly come to minus 57%.
The reason that it comes to more than that is because of the store closures.
But if we model that drop in sales and say, well, what variable costs would automatically drop out of the business, it will be around 20% drop in those central overheads.

If we assume, as it has done this year, that Directory grows as much as retail declines, then the cost that retail pays for the central overheads will decline, but that will be paid for by the growth in the Directory business.
And put it another way, you would still need those central costs to run the Directory business whether or not you had a retail business.
It's just, in a way, the subsidy that retail will pay will come down.
If you take out those shared costs, all the costs will be reallocated toward Directory, they drop to about 22%.
Further cost savings, we think, can get at around 6%.
These are sort of semi-variable costs.
Things like our retail hubs.
Some of the leases will expire over the next 10 years.
We won't just renew them in the same shape and size, and in fact, we're already looking at plans to consolidate 2 hubs into one which will save us significant amount of money.
So overall, we get to around 52% of the central overheads.
That's around GBP 120 million of cost.
Model that across the entire portfolio, and this is -- these are making allowances for 2 things.

First of all, continued spend of capital on cosmetics, still spending GBP 16 million a year all the way through on cosmetics, and also assuming that wages continue to grow faster than inflation by around 1%.
Put those together, you end up with cash flow of around GBP 1 billion.
So when we're thinking about sort of asset or liability, we think actually, even in this worst case scenario, asset of GBP 1 billion.
If you look at the minus 2%, that GBP 1 billion would come to around GBP 2 billion.
So we think the retail portfolio, as an asset to the businesses, were in terms of future cash flow somewhere between GBP 1 billion and GBP 2 billion.
And you can all go through and discount that at the rates you like and come to sort of nitty gritty valuation, which I'm sure we'll enjoy.
However, it's not quite the whole story because some of the assumptions we've made are definitely not right.
First of all, we will open new stores; and secondly, we will -- are more than likely, in an environment of minus 6% like-for-like sales, to experience some rent reductions.
Taking each one of those in turn.
And I feel I have re-explain this many, many times because it is so counterintuitive.
People say, "Why on earth are you opening stores in an environment of declining like-for-like sales?"
And it's a very good question.
And the reason we're opening stores is because the stores we're opening have a quick payback and high profit.
And if we take a store, and this is what we do now, it's a discipline when we open new stores, and say, let's model the minus 6% on the new store that we opened.
So let's take a store, and for ease, say, we invest GBP 1 million in the capital expenditure on that store.
With a 24-month payback, and I should say our 24-month payback assumes 0 like-for-likes, so actually flat, [FX] going down, it would be slightly more than 24 months.
But that means in year 1, you would expect to get cash out of that store of GBP 0.5 million.

Model the cash forward, and you'd expect -- and this is on the basis of a minus 6% like-for-like scenario in that chart, you would expect to get 2.5% -- sorry, GBP 2.5 million back for your GBP 1 million investment.
So as counterintuitive though it is to invest in a store with a declining profit, in cash terms, it's actually a good investment.
And if I put it in another way, if I said, "I've got a bond, and the bond will pay you 50% interest in year 1, but in year 10 will only pay you 4%," you would all buy instantly.
So -- and that is the way that we look at these stores.
We're taking very, very few stores in more than 10-year leases.
Incidentally, the internal rate of return on the money invested in that, if you take the model, run an IRR on it, it comes to around 34%.
So really healthy use of the businesses' capital.
And obviously, the more of these stores were opening, the more of that central overhead we are also recovering.
The second thing is rent reductions.
We have come to the end of 8 stores.
Remember that we closed 10 stores at the end of their lease; another 8, we renewed.
If we look at the rent on those 8 stores, the rent before was GBP 2.9 million; after, GBP 2.2 million.
I should say that GBP 2.2 million accounts for any capital contribution amortizing over the life of the lease.
So that takes the rent to sales in those stores from 9.5% to 7%.
In addition, with open concessions in those stores of around -- which will generate rental income of around GBP 175,000, that's mainly cafs.
That takes the rent-to-sales ratio to 6.5%.
The capital required to maintain a lease -- we normally do go back and spend some capital to maintain a shop, but the average lease length of these renewals is around 7 years.
And the profitability of the stores that we'd renewed on once we've renewed -- reviewed the rent is 23%.

So again, the assumption in our model that we won't get rent reductions certainly in an environment of minus 6% like-for-like, all our experience suggests that, that isn't right and that we would see rent reductions.
I'm just going to talk a little bit about that concession number of GBP 175,000.
At the moment, the vast majority of our concessions are small cafs.
They generate quite a lot of rent, around GBP 4.5 million, GBP 5 million of rent for the group.
But the main purpose is to make the stores more enjoyable places that people want to go.
In Arndale, we're introducing a whole range of different concessions to see what effect they have and whether they're successful or not.

Now as the Chairman said at the beginning, we're a business that likes to try things in a small way, see if they work, don't assume all of these work and suddenly every next door is going to have a hairdresser and a gym and a restaurant, they won't.
But we are going to try all of these things to see 2 things.
One is do they pay the rent, do they make money?
And the second is, can they enhance the look and feel of the store to make them places that people are more likely to want to go?
In terms of restaurants, I should just say we've done a deal with a company called International Restaurants Group, which is basically a Gino DAcampo brand restaurant.
We'll be opening 2 of those stores: 1 in Manchester, 1 in Hull.
And the profit that they'll make for NEXT, we estimated being around GBP 300,000.
So not a lot of profit, that's a 50% share of the profit of those restaurants.
And the real thing is not the profit they make, it's what effect they have on the shop.
So that's all I'm going to say about retail.
I think I'll finish by saying that the retail business, whilst it may make less money going forward, we don't think it will make a loss.
And as long as it doesn't make a loss, we have to recognize that it does provide an enormous benefit to Directory.
More than 40% of our orders by value are collected from store, and that's by value.
In terms of actual numbers of orders, it's more than that, because the average order value going to store is lower.
So more than 50% of the customers ordering from NEXT choose to have their stock delivered to a store.
80% of our returns come back through stores.
Now you might think, well, returns are a bad thing.
If we shut the stores, we'd get less returns.
We would get less returns, but we'd also sell less stock in the first place because the confidence that you can return stock is very important.
You might also ask, and it'd be good question, why the difference between the 50% collect from the store and 80% return to store.
And the answer is that you have to be in for -- to do a return.
You don't necessarily have to be in for a delivery.
The delivery driver can leave it safe, they can leave it in your porch, they can leave it with your neighbor.
And final thing is that 15% of our -- the customers we recruit for Directory, we recruit through our stores.
And I should -- I suppose I can't stress this enough, the stores are a huge asset to Directory, but we don't put any financial value on it at all within our retail accounts.
In terms of Directory modernization, this -- it's taken a long time.
We started this process 18 months ago.
We brought in a huge number of systems.
We changed a large number of people.
We'd employed a lot of new people.
And the benefits are just beginning to come through into our sales numbers, really sort of from March onwards.
If you look back, those are brand sales by month.
We've grouped March and April together because Easter moved between the 2 of them.
But you can see broadly an upward slope.
If you break that down into retail and Directory, you can see that the acceleration in Directory growth has been far, far higher than the acceleration in retail growth.
We think the retail growth, a lot of that was about better weather in June and July.
So you shouldn't get too excited about that.
The Directory acceleration, there's definitely a weather effect there as well.
And we could see on days that were suddenly warm in June and July, they got huge boost in sales, don't underestimate that.
But there is, we believe, something more going on.
Just running through some of the investments we've made.
We've invested around GBP 5.5 million in new proprietary software.
These systems, I think, are like a web merchandising system.
This allows us to deliver different content to different customers at any one point in time.

We bought a database analytics program that allows us to segment our customers more effectively; content management system that allows us to deliver far more content to our website with much less labor.
At the moment, the -- or rather historically, the process of producing different [pieces] created for our Directory was extremely cumbersome and took a lot of labor.
With the data management platform, this allows us to selectively serve different adverts to our customers or customers that we recognize through a cookie on third-party websites and social media.
So this will allow us to do that thing that --- where you look at something on a website, and then it follows you around to other places.
It allows us to do that.
We won't necessarily do it that crudely.

[Obviously,] it would be more effective to show people things that were like the thing that they looked at but didn't buy rather than the thing they looked at and didn't buy, but we'll see about that.

Invested quite a lot of money in security, and we have bought a new credit platform that allows us -- we're not using this yet, but it will allows us going forward to introduce new credit offers for our customers beyond the traditional Directory account.
Of that GBP 5.5 million, around GBP 4.5 million was spent in -- or will be spent in the current year.
And within our forecasts, that's all written off as a revenue cost.
In terms of people, we've taken on 110 -- 121 new people.
Lion's share of that is in development and data, but we've also taken on additional content people, people -- additional people to design new flows through our website.
And we've also invested in security and testing stuff to make sure that our systems are robust.
In many ways, we would have liked to take on more people.
The constraint there, I should stress, hasn't been money, it's just -- gets to the point where taking on too many people actually begins to have a negative effect.
So we've got -- we can't take on people at such a rate of speed that we have a lot of untrained, unmanaged people in the business who don't know what they're doing.
So we will see that number, I think, creeping up over the next 2 or 3 years.
Those add about GBP 6.5 million of additional cost.
GBP 12 million of total costs added to the Directory cost base through software and people.
The reason that's a GBP 1 million more than the GBP 11 million we told you at our last report is because GBP 1 million of that was spent last year on software.
Just in terms of a few of the things that we improved.
We've now rolled out our mobile site across all handsets and via all methods of access.
So we have a fully adaptive site.
Whether you come through Google or go through next.co.uk, you'll be served with our mobile site.
27% -- in January 2016, 27% of orders came by mobile, with a conversion rate of 4.2%.
38% at the moment and with a conversion rate of 5.3%.
That's an improvement of 26%.

I should stress that the orders participation, going from 26% to 38%, would probably have happened anyway because more and more people are ordering online and ordering through their mobile sets anyway.
The improvement in conversion rate wouldn't have happened without the improvements that we've made.
Please don't make the mistake that we initially made when we saw this number, thinking, "Hey, we're going to increase our sales by 26% on all those customers."
An improvement in conversion rate is always balanced to some extent by a reduction in the number of times the customer comes back to the site.
Often, when people fail to buy something, they will come back and have another bash at it.
So it's not quite as good as it looks.
In terms of NextUnlimited.
Remember, we talked about this before.
This is where we deliver -- you get a year's unlimited free deliveries to home from an upfront charge of GBP 20.
The cost of that in the current year, we think, will be around GBP 5 million of lost delivery income.
And that will -- at the moment, more than 10% of our orders are being delivered free-to-home because of NextUnlimited.
And the sales increase we're getting from the customers that have Unlimited is more than enough to pay for the GBP 5 million of cost, of lost handling charge.
But it does mean long term, we'll see margins -- hopefully, sales moving up but margins moving down as a result of less delivery income.
It is worth noting that with more than 50% of our orders going through stores, at the moment, more than 60% of the orders NEXT customers make, in one way or another, are going to them without charge.
We rebranded our account NEXT Pay.
Remember, we were very worried 2 years ago about our credit business.
It was in significant decline.
We rebranded it NEXT Pay.
The rebranding didn't make very much difference at all, but all the promotion we did around that has made a significant difference.
Jan 16, our credit customer base was 6% down on the previous year.
As we stand today, our credit customer base is fractionally up on last year, about 0.2% up on last year.
Don't do that wonderful thing of taking your ruler and drawing a straight line and projecting into wonderful growth in our customer -- credit customer base over the next few years.
We think, at best, we will stabilize our credit customer base.
And the reason that we expect this growth to moderate going forward -- and you can see how the line is beginning to flatten as we go from January to July.
And the reason for that is we begin to annualize the point at which we started to promote credit.
So -- and as we reach that point, we're seeing the rates of growth in credit customers moderate.
So we think, at best at the moment, we think just it will hold steady, our credit customer base.

We do have something (inaudible) that I mentioned earlier, by the end of the year, we will have launched at least one new credit product, which we hope will increase the amount of customers who want credit from NEXT.
The personalized homepages.
Very crudely, you saw men's, women's, children's, various customers will get different homepages.
Of the customers who are served personalized homepages, which is only around 40% of our customer base, we see about a 1% improvement in sales, so a fraction of 0.4% across the group.

And I would stress that all of the little changes we made, all the little tweaks we've done, although they're all super-clever and wonderful, of themselves, only give you a fractional increase in sales.
But added together, they seem to have a multiplier effect and are making a significant difference.
Things like, for example, intelligent recommendations.
When you look at an item now, you will see other items that customers who have viewed that item have also viewed.
We now have bags across devices live, which resulted in around 2% reduction in abandoned baskets.
And we've implemented all of these things across our U.K.
site but not overseas.
So overseas system, with all of these things, in order to implement overseas, it will take us a while.
We prioritized our U.K.
site because it takes the majority of our business.
But over the next 18 months, we'll begin to implement all of these things across our overseas sites.
In terms of things to come, fast checkout and fast registration will come in the second half of the year.
That's just reducing the number of pages our customers have to see in order to check out.
We're going to do much more to target our e-mails, and much more to target our advertising.
I mentioned earlier, the system allows you to personalize adverts for individually recognized customers on third-party sites.
When it comes to all the software that we bought, it was described to me as like someone who's just bought a Ferrari and is driving at a 10 miles an hour around a local supermarket shopping carpark.
We haven't really scratched the surface of using our stuff.
We've started to experiment with targeting e-mails and advertising, but we have got masses and masses to do on this front.
So none of the, I think, any of the benefits we're getting at the moment in sales are coming from the 90% of the software that we bought but we're not using.
So there's still masses more to do on this.
The final thing we'll do, and this probably won't be implemented until next year, is we'll have a new search engine within our website.
Our search engine at the moment is adequate but no better than adequate.
It's really -- it doesn't, in any way, learn.

The search engine that we will be implementing will be an artificial intelligence-driven search engine that will begin to learn from what people are searching for and what they end up actually buying, and begin to put the things they actually buy into the search results as they gain more confidence in what people are really looking for rather than things that we [thread them].
So those are all the improvements that we've made to Directory.
In terms of the business going forward, we are -- I think the words we've used is we believe the environment is less challenging than we thought it was 6 months ago.
Please -- I notice that with a small upgrade of 1% in our profits and some modest words of encouragement, the market has reacted to that, but it's normal exuberance.
But I think -- I wouldn't want to get carried away.
We think that they are less challenging than they were.
Things are definitely not looking as black as they did 6 months ago, but we're still in tough times.
We're still, a bit, seeing this effect.

These are the August number from -- August numbers from Barclaycard in terms of spending on entertainment experiential type expenditure, pubs, restaurants and other forms of entertainment versus women's clothing.
You can see we're still seeing a shift away from clothing into more experiential sales.
Our impression is that, that is getting no worse.
I wouldn't want to go as far as to say it's getting better, but I think that -- I think we've hit the bottom of that cycle, but we could be wrong about that.
In terms of average earnings, average earnings still weighing on the consumer, 1% drop in real income.
But don't lose sight of the fact that employment is up by 1.2%.
So as much as the average consumer will be feeling 1% poorer in real terms, there are 1% more people earning income.
And that, I think to some extent, is the reason why the fall in real income isn't resulting in a sharper fall in consumer expenditure as you might expect.
In terms of our own costs, this year, in the spring/summer, our costing rate, this is the rate at which we were able to lock-in to buying dollars, was down 10%.
Autumn/winter, down 14% as a result of better negotiation, moving stock from more expensive to less expensive sources of supply.
We managed to contain price increases to around 4% in both seasons.
We think it's interesting that the inflation figures that just came out for August were also about 4% increase in prices.
So we don't think we're a million miles away from the market.
Spring/summer, although we still -- our costing rate is still 9% lower than it was last year, we anticipate these price increases next year will be no more than 2% and maybe less than that.
And autumn/winter, although we haven't bought our currency yet, currently, the spot rate is higher than our costing rate for this autumn/winter.
So we expect prices to be flat in autumn/winter at worst.
So what we can see medium term is an end to the cost price inflation bubble that's passed through our sector as we go into next year.
And that should alleviate pressure on the clothing sector.
So those are the 3 external things.
Last time in February, I talked to you about some of the issues that we were having.
I think at the time we said omissions because we didn't want to use the word mistakes.
But now we're past them, I can talk about mistakes.
It's allowed.

We talked about some of the omissions and errors in our ranges for spring and summer, and we sort of gave you this very scientific view as to the level of improvement we were expecting throughout the course of the year.
That has pretty much panned out.
Most of the improvement in sales in the second quarter was about the weather.
And you shouldn't be under any illusions about that.
But some of it, we think, was coming from a modest improvement in the ranges, some of the surgery we were able to do to the ranges.

Going forward, we expect, and the evidence that we've seen so far of our third quarter ranges, is that we are much, much more comfortable with them, and we think that they'll be exactly where we want them in quarter 4, exactly as the [take] cost model indicates.

However, and this is something I want to warn you of because I'm worried that when we announce our quarter 3 sales, you may rush off and think, well, quarter 4 will be better than quarter 3 because I said the ranges are better.
But we're not actually expecting it's pan out like that.
We are forecasting minus 2.8% to plus 3.8% in the second half.
The midpoint of that guidance is plus 0.5%.
However, we're expecting the third quarter, and you'll notice carefully gradated lines here.
So no use of rulers to work out what our internal estimates are largely because we don't really have internal estimates by quarter.
So we just want to give an indication that we expect the third quarter to be better than the fourth quarter, and that's because last year, the third quarter was a disaster.
So if we compare the third quarter last year, we said at that time, the third quarter was 3.5% down.
The Christmas trading statements, the fourth quarter was 0.4% down.
So please don't assume that our fourth quarter trading statement will be better than our third.
So that's it for the outlook section.
The U.K.
economy and the clothing environment does remain extremely challenging, and we think it is going to be -- continue to be a struggle for the foreseeable future.
But we can see no evidence of things getting any worse.
Our stores are, we believe, an asset, albeit an asset that may decline in value, they remain an asset for the business.
And Directory is showing some encouraging signs as a result of the surgery that we have put into improving our website.
In terms of our sales forecast for the full year, our sales forecast at our trading statement in May was minus 3 to plus 0.5%.
We upgraded that slightly in August, and we're nudging it forward again at the moment.
We expect sales for the full year now to be between minus 2% and plus 1.5%.
With the -- and if you want to sort of land on a pinhead, the midpoint of minus 0.25, 0.3 at the midpoint.
If we look at our profit forecast at that midpoint, this is how it pans out.
We still estimate there's a loss of money through negative like-for-like sales.
Our cost increases now, we think, will be broadly offset by cost savings.
Some of these cost savings, incidentally, are a bit of a cheat cost savings.
They're things like a reduction in depreciation, so they're not necessarily cash, but we set all the cost increases and cost savings out in our CEO's report.
So you can see exactly what they are.
New space, we still think, will add GBP 9 million, and Directory, a further GBP 25 million.
All things being equal, we'll be throwing our hats in the air and going a big upgrade to GBP 736 million.
However, the poor clearance rates in the spring/summer sale cost us GBP 11 million, and we are anticipating that poorer clearance rates in the winter sale will cost us another GBP 7 million.
And that's how we get back to the midpoint of GBP 717 million and the GBP 7 million upgrade that we've issued today.
Just looking at how that affected profit before tax.
We're saying our profit before tax range is minus 13% to minus 5%.
Growth in EPS, minus 11% to minus 3%.
Ordinary dividend yield of 4%, and special dividend yield, including the undeclared fourth, assuming that we pay that, of 4.7%.
This is off our share price at the beginning of the year, so a total return from dividends of around 8.8% of the company's value at the beginning of the year.

When you add those together, you realize that actually as bad a year as this has been, the fact that our shareholders will have got 8.8% of the value of the company back means that if you take the intrinsic value of the company as measured by earnings per share, that would have moved back by just more than -- at worst case, just more than the special dividends and cash that we paid out.
At best, 5.7% more.
So whilst it has been a very challenging year.

We believe that we've done as much as we can, first of all, to face up to this -- the amount that we can do to improve the business, and secondly, our returning cash to shareholders have guaranteed that our customers, our shareholders are receiving real cash value in a very difficult market.
